trans-unit.source: Rule Groups and Rules
trans-unit.target: Rule Groups and Rules

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Rule Groups and Rules
trans-unit.target: Rule Groups and Rules

trans-unit.source: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>rule group</newTerm> is a named set of claim rules that define which identity claims are passed from identity providers to your relying party application.
trans-unit.target: In <token>firstref_acs</token>, a <newTerm>rule group</newTerm> is a named set of claim rules that define which identity claims are passed from identity providers to your relying party application.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, rule groups are associated with relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, rule groups are associated with relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: A rule group can be used by more than one relying party application and a relying party application can reference more than one rule group.
trans-unit.target: A rule group can be used by more than one relying party application and a relying party application can reference more than one rule group.

trans-unit.source: When <token>secondref_acs</token> receives a token request or a token from an identity provider, it runs through all of the rule groups associated with the relying party application to process the claims in the token.
trans-unit.target: When <token>secondref_acs</token> receives a token request or a token from an identity provider, it runs through all of the rule groups associated with the relying party application to process the claims in the token.

trans-unit.source: All rule groups are run through simultaneously, as are all rules in each rule group (order does not matter).
trans-unit.target: All rule groups are run through simultaneously, as are all rules in each rule group (order does not matter).

trans-unit.source: If the rules cause any new claims to be issued after the run is complete, then the rule groups associated with the relying party application are run through again.
trans-unit.target: If the rules cause any new claims to be issued after the run is complete, then the rule groups associated with the relying party application are run through again.

trans-unit.source: Rule and rule group run process stops when no new claims are issued after the run process completes or after <token>secondref_acs</token> completes ten run through’s (whichever comes first).
trans-unit.target: Rule and rule group run process stops when no new claims are issued after the run process completes or after <token>secondref_acs</token> completes ten run through’s (whichever comes first).

trans-unit.source: You can create and edit rule groups and rules either manually, using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal or programmatically, using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service.
trans-unit.target: You can create and edit rule groups and rules either manually, using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal or programmatically, using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Rules with the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Configuring Rules with the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Creating Rule Groups
trans-unit.target: Creating Rule Groups

trans-unit.source: When you add and configure the properties of a new relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you can also create a rule group associated with this relying party application, because by default, the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option is checked in the <ui>Add Relying Party Application</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: When you add and configure the properties of a new relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you can also create a rule group associated with this relying party application, because by default, the <ui>Create New Rule Group</ui> option is checked in the <ui>Add Relying Party Application</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend that you keep this option selected and thus create a default rule group for your new relying party application.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend that you keep this option selected and thus create a default rule group for your new relying party application.

trans-unit.source: (For more information, see “Rule groups” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.)
trans-unit.target: (For more information, see “Rule groups” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.)

trans-unit.source: You can also add rule groups using the <ui>Rule Groups</ui> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can also add rule groups using the <ui>Rule Groups</ui> section of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Then, as you add relying party applications using the <ui>Add Relying Party Application</ui> page, you can associate them with one or more existing rule groups.
trans-unit.target: Then, as you add relying party applications using the <ui>Add Relying Party Application</ui> page, you can associate them with one or more existing rule groups.

trans-unit.source: Generating Rules
trans-unit.target: Generating Rules

trans-unit.source: After a rule group is created, you can use the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to automatically generate rules.
trans-unit.target: After a rule group is created, you can use the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to automatically generate rules.

trans-unit.source: If you decide to generate rules automatically, you are prompted to select the identity providers for which you want to generate the rules.
trans-unit.target: If you decide to generate rules automatically, you are prompted to select the identity providers for which you want to generate the rules.

trans-unit.source: When the rule group is linked to one or more relying party applications, the identity providers used by those relying party applications are selected by default.
trans-unit.target: When the rule group is linked to one or more relying party applications, the identity providers used by those relying party applications are selected by default.

trans-unit.source: For WS-Federation identity providers, a rule is created for each claim type that is offered in the identity provider’s WS-Federation metadata and this rule passes through the claim type and value.
trans-unit.target: For WS-Federation identity providers, a rule is created for each claim type that is offered in the identity provider’s WS-Federation metadata and this rule passes through the claim type and value.

trans-unit.source: For other identity providers, pass-through rules are generated based on a list of predetermined claim types.
trans-unit.target: For other identity providers, pass-through rules are generated based on a list of predetermined claim types.

trans-unit.source: Viewing, Adding, and Editing Rules
trans-unit.target: Viewing, Adding, and Editing Rules

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal displays all of the rules in a table, where the columns include the <ui>Output Claim</ui> for the rule, the <ui>Claim Issuer</ui> (can be an identity provider or <token>secondref_acs</token>), and a <ui>Description</ui>.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page of the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal displays all of the rules in a table, where the columns include the <ui>Output Claim</ui> for the rule, the <ui>Claim Issuer</ui> (can be an identity provider or <token>secondref_acs</token>), and a <ui>Description</ui>.

trans-unit.source: If you click a given rule in the table you are redirected to the <ui>Edit Claim Rule</ui> page, where the rule may be edited.
trans-unit.target: If you click a given rule in the table you are redirected to the <ui>Edit Claim Rule</ui> page, where the rule may be edited.

trans-unit.source: To add a new rule manually, you can click <ui>Add</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To add a new rule manually, you can click <ui>Add</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Claim Rules
trans-unit.target: Claim Rules

trans-unit.source: Claim rules describe the logic of how <token>secondref_acs</token> transforms input claims into output claims.
trans-unit.target: Claim rules describe the logic of how <token>secondref_acs</token> transforms input claims into output claims.

trans-unit.source: Rules are contained within rule groups, which are associated with relying party applications and are run through whenever a token is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> for an application.
trans-unit.target: Rules are contained within rule groups, which are associated with relying party applications and are run through whenever a token is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> for an application.

trans-unit.source: If a rule group contains no rules, then no token is issued to the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: If a rule group contains no rules, then no token is issued to the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: Typically, one rule is required for every claim type that you want to issue to your relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Typically, one rule is required for every claim type that you want to issue to your relying party application.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to create and use only one rule to pass through all claim types and values.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to create and use only one rule to pass through all claim types and values.

trans-unit.source: However, using a rule per every claim type improves security and provides greater control over the data that is passed to your application.
trans-unit.target: However, using a rule per every claim type improves security and provides greater control over the data that is passed to your application.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can configure a rule to pass a claim received from an identity provider or client through to the relying party application without changing the claim’s type, issuer, or value.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can configure a rule to pass a claim received from an identity provider or client through to the relying party application without changing the claim’s type, issuer, or value.

trans-unit.source: These rules are called <newTerm>pass-through</newTerm> rules.
trans-unit.target: These rules are called <newTerm>pass-through</newTerm> rules.

trans-unit.source: For example, tokens issued by <token>ms_acct</token> contain a <system>nameidentifier</system> claim type.
trans-unit.target: For example, tokens issued by <token>ms_acct</token> contain a <system>nameidentifier</system> claim type.

trans-unit.source: To pass this claim unchanged to the relying party application, you have to configure a pass-through rule that processes the input <system>nameidentifier</system> claim type from the claim issuer, <token>windows_live_id</token>, and creates an identical output claim.
trans-unit.target: To pass this claim unchanged to the relying party application, you have to configure a pass-through rule that processes the input <system>nameidentifier</system> claim type from the claim issuer, <token>windows_live_id</token>, and creates an identical output claim.

trans-unit.source: The table below illustrates claims being passed through from a fictional AD FS 2.0 identity provider named Contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: The table below illustrates claims being passed through from a fictional AD FS 2.0 identity provider named Contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine also provides you with the ability to transform input claims into entirely different output claims, based on the claim issuer, input claim type, and value.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine also provides you with the ability to transform input claims into entirely different output claims, based on the claim issuer, input claim type, and value.

trans-unit.source: In other words, the <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine allows you to transform input tokens into different output tokens by adding, removing, or changing the claims that the tokens contain.
trans-unit.target: In other words, the <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine allows you to transform input tokens into different output tokens by adding, removing, or changing the claims that the tokens contain.

trans-unit.source: This form of claims transformation makes <token>secondref_acs</token> capable of implementing basic authorization based on claim input values.
trans-unit.target: This form of claims transformation makes <token>secondref_acs</token> capable of implementing basic authorization based on claim input values.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows a claim type of “role” with a value of “administrator” being output if the “nameidentifier” input claim matches a specific value.
trans-unit.target: The example below shows a claim type of “role” with a value of “administrator” being output if the “nameidentifier” input claim matches a specific value.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine also provides the ability to create output claims based on a conjunction of two input claims.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> rules engine also provides the ability to create output claims based on a conjunction of two input claims.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the output claim is of type “action” with a value of “write” if both the “nameidentifier” and the “role” input claims from Contoso.com match specific values.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the output claim is of type “action” with a value of “write” if both the “nameidentifier” and the “role” input claims from Contoso.com match specific values.

trans-unit.source: When two input claims are specified in a rule, both values must match to generate the output claim.
trans-unit.target: When two input claims are specified in a rule, both values must match to generate the output claim.

trans-unit.source: For more information and steps about how to implement token transformation using rules, see <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Implement Token Transformation Logic Using Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information and steps about how to implement token transformation using rules, see <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Implement Token Transformation Logic Using Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: When you add new or edit existing claim rules with the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you must configure the following settings:
trans-unit.target: When you add new or edit existing claim rules with the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal, you must configure the following settings:

trans-unit.source: Rule conditions (if) – Adding an Input Claim
trans-unit.target: Rule conditions (if) – Adding an Input Claim

trans-unit.source: This section contains the conditions that must be true for the rule to issue an output claim.
trans-unit.target: This section contains the conditions that must be true for the rule to issue an output claim.

trans-unit.source: These conditions include the following:
trans-unit.target: These conditions include the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Claim issuer</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the entity that issued the input claim.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Claim issuer</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the entity that issued the input claim.

trans-unit.source: This can be a configured identity provider (for example, <token>ssWLiveID</token>) or <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This can be a configured identity provider (for example, <token>ssWLiveID</token>) or <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> is the issuer if the input claim comes from a service identity or the input claim comes from another claim rule.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> is the issuer if the input claim comes from a service identity or the input claim comes from another claim rule.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="52225343-ab35-4455-b3f9-e014d7ac6b78" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Identities</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="52225343-ab35-4455-b3f9-e014d7ac6b78" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Service Identities</link>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the input claim type received from the claim issuer.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the input claim type received from the claim issuer.

trans-unit.source: For example, the full claim type for the “nameidentifier” is http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier.
trans-unit.target: For example, the full claim type for the “nameidentifier” is http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier.

trans-unit.source: The options for this field include:
trans-unit.target: The options for this field include:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if any claim type is received from the issuer.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if any claim type is received from the issuer.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Select type</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the type selected in the drop-down menu.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Select type</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the type selected in the drop-down menu.

trans-unit.source: This menu is populated with available claim types for the selected claim issuer.
trans-unit.target: This menu is populated with available claim types for the selected claim issuer.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the value of the input claim received.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the value of the input claim received.

trans-unit.source: For example, the “nameidentifier” claim type uses an email address as its value and this field can be used to check for a specific email address.
trans-unit.target: For example, the “nameidentifier” claim type uses an email address as its value and this field can be used to check for a specific email address.

trans-unit.source: The options for this field include:
trans-unit.target: The options for this field include:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if any claim value is received from the issuer.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if any claim value is received from the issuer.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.

trans-unit.source: This option requires a specific input claim type to be selected or entered in the <ui>Input Claim Type</ui> field.
trans-unit.target: This option requires a specific input claim type to be selected or entered in the <ui>Input Claim Type</ui> field.

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Rule conditions (if) – Adding a Second Input Claim
trans-unit.target: Rule conditions (if) – Adding a Second Input Claim

trans-unit.source: To add a second claim to the rule, click <ui>Add a second input claim</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To add a second claim to the rule, click <ui>Add a second input claim</ui>.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to specify the additional conditions shown below.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to specify the additional conditions shown below.

trans-unit.source: Note that in a rule with two input claims, all conditions must be true to generate an output claim.
trans-unit.target: Note that in a rule with two input claims, all conditions must be true to generate an output claim.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Claim issuer</ui>—Refers to the entity that issued the second input claim.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Claim issuer</ui>—Refers to the entity that issued the second input claim.

trans-unit.source: This can be the same identity provider selected for the first claim, or it can be <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This can be the same identity provider selected for the first claim, or it can be <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Select <token>secondref_acs</token> to specify claims generated from other claim rules during rules processing.
trans-unit.target: Select <token>secondref_acs</token> to specify claims generated from other claim rules during rules processing.

trans-unit.source: Two different identity providers cannot be selected for the first and second claims, as rules processing only occurs for one token issued from one identity provider at a time.
trans-unit.target: Two different identity providers cannot be selected for the first and second claims, as rules processing only occurs for one token issued from one identity provider at a time.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Input claim type</ui>—Refers to the input claim type received from the claim issuer.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Input claim type</ui>—Refers to the input claim type received from the claim issuer.

trans-unit.source: For example, the full claim type for the “nameidentifier” is http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier.
trans-unit.target: For example, the full claim type for the “nameidentifier” is http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier.

trans-unit.source: The options for this field include:
trans-unit.target: The options for this field include:

trans-unit.source: <ui>Select type</ui>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the type selected in the drop-down menu.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Select type</ui>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the type selected in the drop-down menu.

trans-unit.source: This menu is populated with available claim types for the selected claim issuer.
trans-unit.target: This menu is populated with available claim types for the selected claim issuer.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Enter type</ui>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Enter type</ui>—Returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Input claim value</ui>—Refers to the value of the input claim received.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Input claim value</ui>—Refers to the value of the input claim received.

trans-unit.source: For example, the “nameidentifier” claim type uses an email address as its value and this field can be used to check for a specific email address.
trans-unit.target: For example, the “nameidentifier” claim type uses an email address as its value and this field can be used to check for a specific email address.

trans-unit.source: This returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.
trans-unit.target: This returns true if the input claim type matches the exact value entered in the field.

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Rule actions (then)
trans-unit.target: Rule actions (then)

trans-unit.source: This section specifies the output claim that is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> if the conditions in the <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section of the rule are true.
trans-unit.target: This section specifies the output claim that is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token> if the conditions in the <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section of the rule are true.

trans-unit.source: The output claim options include the following:
trans-unit.target: The output claim options include the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel>—The claim type that is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel>—The claim type that is issued by <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: The options for this field include the following:
trans-unit.target: The options for this field include the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Pass-through input claim type</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim that is of the same type as the input claim.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Pass-through input claim type</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim that is of the same type as the input claim.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Select type</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim of the specified type.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Select type</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim of the specified type.

trans-unit.source: The drop-down menu contains a list of common claim types.
trans-unit.target: The drop-down menu contains a list of common claim types.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>—Issues a claim of the entered type.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>—Issues a claim of the entered type.

trans-unit.source: If the output claim is to be present in a SAML token, then this value must be a URI (for example, http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier).
trans-unit.target: If the output claim is to be present in a SAML token, then this value must be a URI (for example, http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier).

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the value of the output claim issued by <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel>—Refers to the value of the output claim issued by <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: The options for this field include the following:
trans-unit.target: The options for this field include the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Pass-through input claim value</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim with the value identical to the value of the input claim.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Pass-through input claim value</embeddedLabel>—Issues an output claim with the value identical to the value of the input claim.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>—Issues a claim that has the value entered in this field.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>—Issues a claim that has the value entered in this field.

trans-unit.source: This option requires a specific input claim type to be selected or entered in the <ui>Output Claim Type</ui> field.
trans-unit.target: This option requires a specific input claim type to be selected or entered in the <ui>Output Claim Type</ui> field.

trans-unit.source: This field is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: This field is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Rule Information
trans-unit.target: Rule Information

trans-unit.source: You can use this section to create a description for a rule.
trans-unit.target: You can use this section to create a description for a rule.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, rule descriptions are not automatically created for the generated rules.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, rule descriptions are not automatically created for the generated rules.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Rules with the ACS Management Service
trans-unit.target: Configuring Rules with the ACS Management Service

trans-unit.source: Rules in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> can be configured programmatically by using the <link xlink:href="f69b173a-fcf8-4f59-864a-09b05541d3df" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service</link>.
trans-unit.target: Rules in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> can be configured programmatically by using the <link xlink:href="f69b173a-fcf8-4f59-864a-09b05541d3df" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ACS Management Service</link>.

trans-unit.source: For an example of how to configure rules by using ASP.NET, see <link xlink:href="ef05d80b-a5d4-461b-99dc-3e91215340d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: Management Service</link>.
trans-unit.target: For an example of how to configure rules by using ASP.NET, see <link xlink:href="ef05d80b-a5d4-461b-99dc-3e91215340d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Code Sample: Management Service</link>.

trans-unit.source: Below are important items to consider when using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service to configure rules:
trans-unit.target: Below are important items to consider when using the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service to configure rules:

trans-unit.source: When editing and deleting rules in a rule group, it is recommended that you first query <token>secondref_acs</token> for all rules within that rule group, and use the rule IDs that your query returns to perform the edit or delete operations.
trans-unit.target: When editing and deleting rules in a rule group, it is recommended that you first query <token>secondref_acs</token> for all rules within that rule group, and use the rule IDs that your query returns to perform the edit or delete operations.

trans-unit.source: It is not recommended that you store the IDs returned by the management service for future operations, as these IDs are not guaranteed to persist.
trans-unit.target: It is not recommended that you store the IDs returned by the management service for future operations, as these IDs are not guaranteed to persist.

trans-unit.source: If you are writing automatic retry logic for creating rules (such as in the event of a timeout), it is recommended that you first query for the existence of an identical rule in the current rule group before attempting to add it a second time.
trans-unit.target: If you are writing automatic retry logic for creating rules (such as in the event of a timeout), it is recommended that you first query for the existence of an identical rule in the current rule group before attempting to add it a second time.
